summary: This is an email from defense attorney Laura Menninger to Judge Nathan requesting an adjournment of Ghislaine Maxwell's trial and seeking to redact other clients' names from the motion, citing attorney-client confidentiality rules.

persons.name: Laura Menninger
persons.context: Attorney for Ghislaine Maxwell who sends the email requesting trial adjournment and redaction of other clients' names from court filings.

persons.name: Nathan
persons.context: US District Court judge presiding over the Ghislaine Maxwell case who receives the adjournment request.

persons.name: Ghislaine Maxwell
persons.context: The defendant in the criminal case referenced in the email subject line and body.

events.title: Court Order Issued
events.description: Judge Nathan issued an order (Dkt. 221) that prompted the defense's response regarding trial adjournment.

events.title: Defense Requests Trial Adjournment
events.description: Defense counsel Laura Menninger formally requests a 120 or 180-day adjournment of Ghislaine Maxwell's trial.

keyFacts: Defense attorneys for Ghislaine Maxwell requested a significant adjournment (120-180 days) of her trial in April 2021.
The defense cited attorney-client confidentiality rules (Rule of Professional Conduct 1.6) to request redaction of other clients' names from court filings.
The email references legal precedents from Indiana, Kansas, and Oklahoma supporting the confidentiality argument.
The correspondence shows the defense strategy of protecting client information even when it might be publicly available.
The document indicates ongoing pretrial motions and procedural matters in the Maxwell case as of April 2021.
